item.title: How the biggest consumer apps got their first 1,000 users - Issue 25
item.description: Considering every startup confronts this question at some point, I was surprised by how little has been written about it. Particularly anything actionable. So I decided to do my own digging. I spent the past month personally reaching out to founders, scouring interviews, and tapping the Twitterverse. Below, you’ll find first-hand accounts of how essentially every major consumer app acquired their earliest users, including Tinder, Uber, Superhuman, TikTok, Product Hunt, Yelp, and over a dozen more. Enjoy!
item.author: (Lenny Rachitsky)

item.title: 275: Analyzing Squid Game’s Motion Detection (Red Light, Green Light)
item.description: This week we break down the technology in Netflix's hit show Squid Game. We look at the motion sensing and detection technology in episode 1 to find out if it is realistic or just TV magic.

item.title: Introducing experimental OpenTelemetry support in the Azure SDK for .NET
item.description: Cloud-hosted apps are often composed of many services that are integrated together in some fashion. For example, processing a single request might involve: Calling an Azure Storage service. Posting an event to Azure Event Hubs. Calling a custom authentication backend. With an increasing number of moving pieces comes an increasing number of distributed failure points.
item.author: (Pavel Krymets)

item.title: Pop-up from Hell: On the growing opacity of web programs
item.description: What can we learn from an annoying pop-up ad that cannot be closed? In this post, I continue theme that I started in my interactive Commodore 64 BASIC essay, which is to look at past programming systems and see what interesting past ideas have been lost. I look at the growing opacity of web programs and how technologies like WebAssembly and Canvas-based rendering limit extensibility. Is this an accident, or an inevitable law of software evolution?
item.author: (Tomas Petricek)

item.title: Democracy vs Autocracy
item.description: Every group decision falls on a spectrum, from democratic to autocratic. Democratic decisions are derived from consensus, while autocratic decisions are made by a single person. A dictator can be popular as much as a democracy can be tyrannical. Democracy is not inherently good as autocracy is not inherently bad. The success of each style depends on their execution within a context. The Context Autocracy Autocracy has the advantage of efficiency.
item.author: (cam)

item.title: Chrome does some weird stuff if you toggle a stylesheet on and off
item.description: If you re-enable a stylesheet, Chrome may mistakenly try to fetch it again, causing a flash of unstyled content.

item.title: And You Will Know Us by the Company We Keep — Remains of the Day
item.description: It feels as if we're at the tail end of the first era of social media in the West. Looking back at the companies that have survived, certain application architectural choices are ubiquitous. By now, we're all familiar with the infinite vertical scrolling feed of content units, the likes, the follows, the comments, the profile photos and usernames, all those signature design tropes of this Palaeozoic era of social.
item.author: (by Eugene Wei)
